posts.post_content: Anybody that doesn't like this guy is holding out because they love old power and old cards. It is nice to see a new mover and a shaker out on the battlefield. I've played with this, it is powerful, yet it can also be defeated. Black has always had crazy big horrors or demons or whatever that had to be dealt with immediately. I think it even has a relatively classic feel and look on the battlefield, especially when you see the fear in the opponents eyes... third turn, nice; second turn, awesome; first turn, Obliterator!!!

Posted By: VarteDod (4/28/2011 4:20:01 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
It's not like green's not going to play [Beast Within](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Beast Within), heh? Who's complaining that BW is more versatile and, therefore, more likely to be played in large numbers? No one. What makes JTMS great? Versatility. Obliterator is just a "unblockable" beatstick. It fills a very narrow role, in a very limited number of decks. It's not going to pop all over the place and warp the metagame.  
  
I think Wizards realized that as long as they provided a healthy amount of removal for all colors, it was okay to make powerful and flashy creatures. And we're benefiting from it. The whole game thrives on cool creatures with nifty abilities. It's like DnD at higher levels: you can do great things and you feel awesome doing them, but your enemies can do a lot too, so the balance (usually) remains. Everybody's happy. Or should be.
posts.html:
It's not like green's not going to play Beast Within, heh? Who's complaining that BW is more versatile and, therefore, more likely to be played in large numbers? No one. What makes JTMS great? Versatility. Obliterator is just a "unblockable" beatstick. It fills a very narrow role, in a very limited number of decks. It's not going to pop all over the place and warp the metagame.

I think Wizards realized that as long as they provided a healthy amount of removal for all colors, it was okay to make powerful and flashy creatures. And we're benefiting from it. The whole game thrives on cool creatures with nifty abilities. It's like DnD at higher levels: you can do great things and you feel awesome doing them, but your enemies can do a lot too, so the balance (usually) remains. Everybody's happy. Or should be.

posts.post_content:
I wouldn't say he's broken, he's just good. But also very vulerable. Although I run mono-black centered around him and swinging big and for me it is extremely fun, so I'm gonna continue using him. With the banning of Jace and Stoneforge there will be a lot more room for big creatures like this. No longer will you fear [Jace, the Mind Sculptor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace, the Mind Sculptor) dropping in and bouncing your fatties, or [Stoneforge Mystic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stoneforge Mystic)'s sword equipped hawks.
  
   
But seriously, if this guy bothers you just hit him with [Dismember](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dismember).

Posted By: Kitty_the_Kat (6/22/2011 1:39:00 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This card showcases the benefits of playing Mono-Black. Cards like [Lashwrithe](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lashwrithe) and [Nightmare](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nightmare) already push the theme, but an all-around powerhouse like this really give the "devote your whole being to black" theme. Personally, I love it. The card's got great flavor, amazing artwork, and is just powerful for a 4CMC.   
  
And honestly it's not that broken. Magic knew what they were unleashing on the current standard, that's why the made cards like [Dismember](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dismember) (which shuts this guy down completely) and [Dispatch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dispatch) etc. This cards triggered ability only further lays down the Red hate (you do NOT want to burn this guy to death), but burn typically already has a problem with dealing with 5+ toughness creatures.  
  
4.5/5 for trying to entice players to go Mono-Black. Or at least run Dark Rituals and Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth.
posts.html:
This card showcases the benefits of playing Mono-Black. Cards like Lashwrithe and Nightmare already push the theme, but an all-around powerhouse like this really give the "devote your whole being to black" theme. Personally, I love it. The card's got great flavor, amazing artwork, and is just powerful for a 4CMC.

And honestly it's not that broken. Magic knew what they were unleashing on the current standard, that's why the made cards like Dismember (which shuts this guy down completely) and Dispatch etc. This cards triggered ability only further lays down the Red hate (you do NOT want to burn this guy to death), but burn typically already has a problem with dealing with 5+ toughness creatures.

4.5/5 for trying to entice players to go Mono-Black. Or at least run Dark Rituals and Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth.

posts.post_content:
To deal with this you need:  
Deathtouch  
Non-damage removal (exile, destroy, -X/-X, into-library, bounce)  
Damage redirection (lawl)  
Ablative Permanents or Health (I.E. don't deal with it)  
Mind control  
Temporary Mind Control (red)  
Stifle  
Creature becomes X/Y and loses all abilities  
Counters  
Abilities that do any of the above  
Maybe more stuff.  
  
  
After reading my old comment I've realized that the Mirran side was mostly red/white. Red being terrible against this thing ends up making much more sense flavor-wise when you realize that red is the actual enemy of this card. Also interesting to note, it's good even against double or first strike.   
  
That said,  
@Cheza  
I have like.. 3 Demon tribal decks because the demons are so awesome. I utilize everything from mass reanimation/dredge (like opening hell itself to piss forth demons) to the morph demons to hardcast them super early, to simply using the demons who come with free mass-removal (havoc, carnifex, pestilence, reiver.) When it comes to c... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
